interesting that you started out with a reference to a sports car. The same thing happens with high performance carburetors. The phenomenon is called standoff. The note from the engine creates a standing wave in the carburetor horn while the car idles. This wave aggregates the gasoline droplets, which "walk" backwards out of the horn. This often causes engine fires, typically while waiting at red lights.

Hey there I have a question with your animation and description on how this actually works at 1:26. You said that the material being levitated is inserted into pressure nodes, where the change in pressure is equal to zero. This also corresponds to a displacement node, where the particles of the medium experience maximum displacement back and forth. With this maximum displacement of the medium (air), an equal amount of particles are being moved out as they are moved in, and thus no pressure change.

From how I am thinking about it, however, I thought that the material could only be placed in the pressure antinodes specifically p_max areas, where the pressure of either side of the medium squeezes the material in one spot, and thus levitating it, but this does not seem to be the case.

You can levitate objects with electricity as well in theory. If you point the top loads of two tesla coils operating 180 degrees out of phase to each other, the points in space between two top loads where nodes are formed from two electric waves cancelling each other is where objects can be placed for electrical acoustic levitation. But you likely need to rectify AC or DC to Tesla's LC (Longitudinal Current) first so you can have electricity behaving like a sound wave. Fortunately its easy to produce longitudinal electricity with only capacitors and coils connected in certain way. For circuit diagram, google "The L.M.D./T.E.M.Test - JLN Labs" and for demonstration of Tesla's longitudinal electric waves, google "Transverse & Longitudinal Electric Waves and Tesla’s Longitudinal Electricity" by electrical engineer Eric Dollard. Longitudinal electricity has electric field and magnetic field flowing in same direction as you can see in this video "Replication of Eric Dollard's Analog Computer". You can easily measure it with Trifield meter.

I know I’m way late on this, but this phenomenon (the levitation, not exactly the breaking) can be seen in the atmosphere.

Here in the Northwest we often get moist air at relatively low levels flowing in from the ocean, and due to the terrain, the laminar flow is disturbed creating “ripples” in a way.

When you watch a loop of the satellite under the right conditions, you can see numerous clear air lines in between the clouds at regular intervals perpendicular to the airflow.

These clouds are often referred to as Standing Wave Clouds.

Average does not denote maximum or minimum. The average maximum a human can hear is 20kHz, but that means that some hear below and some hear above. The "average" human is 5'4". This does not mean no human will hit their head on a 5'5" door frame. For example, when I was younger I could hear dog fences, several dog whistles, a whine from electronics no one else can (one of the reasons I'm so happy CRT TVs are a thing of the past, though even some flatscreens emit the tone). And I think this was one of the reasons I had so many headaches--audio overload.

So when you say, "You can't hear this", and play the sound you think we can't hear, some of us can and it can be painful. An average does not denote a maximum or a minimum.

The problem with this is that there are relatively few possibilities for practical implementation of acoustic levitation. The thought that would probably immediately enter most people's minds would probably be the idea for sonic engines for a space/aerocraft, but as this machine demonstrates, that's not possible because the source of the frequency has to be an isolated entity supporting a free-floating object. The pressure difference caused by this change in shape further flattens the drop until it gets too thin and bursts.

While I'm not a physicist, it looks like there may be two phenomena happening here. Drops look like they're bursting due to becoming too large when you inject a large drop. When you ramp up the amplitude, it looks like the drops flatten and then burst. My hypothesis is that the second type of burst is due to pressure shear. More precisely, the "pocket" in which a droplet can exist without being destroyed by pressure variations as you move away from the node of the standing wave becomes too small to support a drop.

I don't know how narrow the bandwidth of the ultrasound emitter is, but I have to wonder if injecting a side tone might let you explode the drops sequentially.

When amplitude is changed the two waves squish the drops, they don't actually "explode" rather the two incoming waves force them out of the way.

A simple way to visualize this would be to take two pieces plastic document covers (the kind found on spiraled notebooks we use in school projects etc) and put a drop of water in the middle. Then by pressing with our fingers two such covers over the drop the water in the center of the pressure point is forced to vacate that spot.

Same here. I suspect that if the two waves were stronger not just in the vertical axis but also a bit more in to the sides say 30 degrees around from the emission point and with a single drop we'd tweak the "threshold" then we could have a squished drop that would stay that way.

I also think that the amplitude is not fine enough, being controlled by hand thus, why the drops "explode".

Has anyone considered using those military directional speakers? As i understand those are perfectly directional. Standing outside the "beam" you can't hear them even when you're right next to them.

Just my two cents.
